advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>These in an advert from 84, for 3 models of Hectors (Hector 16k, Hector 2HR+ 48k & Hector HRX 64k).</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> POPULAR ELECTRONICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover and extracts of a 6 page article in the January 1975 issue of Popular Electronics</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad is unique in that it features professional actors and IMSAI employees. <p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www1.cts.ne.jp/~sato/hp/">Sato's Homepage</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (APRIL 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <http://www.classiccmp.org/dunfield/miscpm/" target="_blank">Dave Dunfield</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ONTEL ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks also to <b>Bob Hanrahan</b> for these pictures</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Welcome in the world of the "clean"-computers"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thank you boss !" <br><br> The ad incite employees to ask their boss to buy these Apricot systems...clever.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> F.D. UNIT ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>BBC floppy disc unit was delivered with a 8271 FD controller chip and a Filing System software in ROM to be fitted into the BBC system.<br> Two versions of F.D. units were available:<br> - A single drive unit, single side, single density, 100 KB space.<br> - A dual drive version, double side, double density, 800 KB space. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #4 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #7</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HP-150 was widely used in industry by engineers and scientists.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT MULTIPLAN, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to chrism3667 for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.spies.com/~aek/orphanage.html" target="_blank">The Minicomputer Orphanage</a> website</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT APR. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl ! Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983 </strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably the last advert made by T.I. in the UK</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
Comart was the computer system group that took over the Byte Shop/Computerland chain when it had financial difficulties in the late 70s. They were a large company distributing North Star systems, and similar equipments. The Communicator was their first effort in distributing a British-made system.
The Communicator is a S-100 bus system based around a main chassis with a 10-slot-mother-board. The system had 64 KB of RAM and came with three variations of dual floppy disk drives.
Several S-100 boards were available. They offered Viewdata/Prestel capabilities, or 18.7 MB hard disk, with 13.4 MB cartridge backup.
The system ran CP/M operating system. A smaller system called the Educator, with networking facilities, was also available.
Chris Coggins adds: The Communicator was upgraded over several years until the Communicator was given multi-user capability by running MP/M80 but finished off running Intel 386 processors with 512 KB RAM running CCP/M86. Hard disk had grown to 40MB Rodime drive. David Broad sold Comart to Kode International and 2 years later it lefts it's Cambridgeshire factory and moved to Swindon. The Company went downhill, dropped the S-100 bus to use standard PC architecture but eventually closed.
computer.media: 2 x 5.25'' floppy disc drives - 190 KB, 390 KB or 790 KB each
computer.name: Communicator
computer.text: Depends on the video terminal used
